See Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Co.raw_text: See Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
See Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Co.proposition: See Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing an implied warranty of habitability and the use of housing-code standards to determine violations); accord cases and authorities cited below.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: See, e.g., Javins, 428 F.2d at 1074–76; Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984); Park West Management v. Mitchell, 47 Cal.App.3d 14 (1975) (recognizing landlord obligations in the face of serious housing defects).
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The proposition is that Hilder is an example of a case recognizing landlord obligations in the face of serious housing defects. Hilder explicitly adopts an implied warranty of habitability in all residential leases, makes the landlord’s duty to provide safe, clean, and fit premises an interdependent obligation with the tenant’s duty to pay rent, and applies that doctrine to serious conditions such as sewage, inoperable plumbing, and unsafe ceilings. The court affirms substantial tenant remedies based on the landlord’s failure to correct these serious defects, directly supporting the cited proposition.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. … Additionally, the implied warranty of habitability covers all latent and patent defects in the essential facilities of the residential unit. … When, as in the instant case, the tenant seeks, not to escape rent liability, but to receive compensatory damages in the amount of rent already paid, abandonment is similarly unnecessary.”

Park West Management v. Mitchell, 47 Cal.raw_text: Park West Management v. Mitchell, 47 Cal.App.3d 14 (1975)
Park West Management v. Mitchell, 47 Cal.proposition: See, e.g., Javins, 428 F.2d at 1074–76; Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984); Park West Management v. Mitchell, 47 Cal.App.3d 14 (1975) (recognizing landlord obligations in the face of serious housing defects).
Park West Management v. Mitchell, 47 Cal.support_reasoning: This opinion is a California criminal case about assault and battery on police officers, addressing jury instructions on oral admissions, reasonable doubt regarding officers acting in the performance of their duties, and merger of assault into battery. It does not concern landlord–tenant law, habitability, or landlord obligations regarding housing defects. The citation to this case for recognizing landlord obligations in the face of serious housing defects is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding.
Park West Management v. Mitchell, 47 Cal.relevant_excerpt: Lopez also correctly contends he "cannot be properly convicted of both assault and battery on Officer Harvey. Every battery includes an assault and is, in fact, a consummated assault. (People v. Heise, 217 Cal. 671, 673 [20 P.2d 317]; 1 Witkin, Cal. Crimes, § 255, p. 241.) Assault is a necessarily included offense in battery and the jury should have been instructed that it could convict Lopez of either of the two offenses charged, but not both. (People v. Toliver, 270 Cal.App.2d 492, 498 [75 Cal.Rptr. 819].)"

Gagnon v. Residence Exchange, Inc., 261.proposition: Case Law (representative authorities addressing covenant of quiet enjoyment, implied warranty of habitability, habitability standards, and landlord obligations to abate infestations and maintain premises):

Jardine v. Morgenthau, 234 Mass. 304 (19.proposition: Case Law (representative authorities addressing covenant of quiet enjoyment, implied warranty of habitability, habitability standards, and landlord obligations to abate infestations and maintain premises):

Commonwealth v. Shay, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 3.raw_text: Commonwealth v. Shay, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 338 (1975)
Commonwealth v. Shay, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 3.proposition: Case Law (representative authorities addressing covenant of quiet enjoyment, implied warranty of habitability, habitability standards, and landlord obligations to abate infestations and maintain premises):
Commonwealth v. Shay, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 3.support_reasoning: The opinion in Commonwealth v. Shay does not concern landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, implied warranty of habitability, habitability standards, or landlord obligations to abate infestations or maintain premises. It addresses fiduciary duties of an attorney in a business transaction with a client and the consequences of the attorney’s overreaching. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the habitability or landlord-tenant propositions described.
Commonwealth v. Shay, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 3.relevant_excerpt: "The relationship of attorney and client is highly fiduciary in nature... The law looks with great disfavor upon an attorney who has business dealings with his client which result in gains to the attorney at the expense of the client. 'The attorney is not permitted by the law to take any advantage of his client. The principles holding the attorney to a conspicuous degree of faithfulness and forbidding him to take personal advantage of his client are thoroughly established.'"

Smith v. Roberts, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 123.raw_text: Smith v. Roberts, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (1986)
Smith v. Roberts, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 123.proposition: Case Law (representative authorities addressing covenant of quiet enjoyment, implied warranty of habitability, habitability standards, and landlord obligations to abate infestations and maintain premises):
Smith v. Roberts, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 123.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal appeal from a rape conviction and deals with evidentiary and trial issues (cross-examination for bias, expert medical testimony, fresh complaint, hospital records, etc.). It does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, the implied warranty of habitability, habitability standards, or duties to abate infestations. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition relating to landlord obligations and habitability doctrines.
Smith v. Roberts, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 123.relevant_excerpt: The defendant was convicted of rape and assault and battery... He raises issues concerning: (1) the exclusion of questions designed to show that the alleged victim had a motive to lie; (2) the refusal, to exclude a doctor’s diagnosis of the victim’s condition; (3) the refusal to give a limiting instruction with respect to an array of photographs... (4) the refusal to exclude the hospital records of the victim; (5) the refusal to exclude testimony of the victim as to her own fresh complaints... For the reasons stated below, we affirm the convictions.

Wilson v. Reddy, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 564 (.raw_text: Wilson v. Reddy, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 564 (1995)
Wilson v. Reddy, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 564 (.proposition: Case Law (representative authorities addressing covenant of quiet enjoyment, implied warranty of habitability, habitability standards, and landlord obligations to abate infestations and maintain premises):
Wilson v. Reddy, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 564 (.support_reasoning: Wilson v. Reddy is a criminal case involving aggravated rape and assault; it does not concern landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, the implied warranty of habitability, habitability standards, or landlord obligations to address infestations or maintain premises. The opinion focuses on evidentiary issues (fresh complaint), the aggravated rape statute, sentencing, and ineffective assistance of counsel. It therefore does not provide authority for the landlord-tenant propositions for which it is cited.
Wilson v. Reddy, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 564 (.relevant_excerpt: The defendant was convicted by a Superior Court jury of one indictment charging aggravated rape, two indictments charging assault and battery by means of a dangerous weapon, and one indictment charging assault and battery. He appeals from the convictions on the grounds that the trial judge erred (1) in admitting in evidence fresh complaint testimony... (2) in denying his motion for a required finding of not guilty on the aggravated rape charge... and (3) in imposing a sentence of from twenty to twenty-five years on the aggravated rape conviction... We affirm the convictions.

DiPalermo v. Commercial Union Ins. Co.,.raw_text: DiPalermo v. Commercial Union Ins. Co., 398 Mass. 624 (1986)
DiPalermo v. Commercial Union Ins. Co.,.proposition: Case Law (representative authorities addressing covenant of quiet enjoyment, implied warranty of habitability, habitability standards, and landlord obligations to abate infestations and maintain premises):
DiPalermo v. Commercial Union Ins. Co.,.support_reasoning: The opinion provided is Commonwealth v. Mayfield, a criminal case about grand jury integrity, evidentiary issues, and trial procedure in a murder prosecution. It does not address landlord-tenant law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the implied warranty of habitability, habitability standards, or landlord obligations regarding infestations or maintenance. Therefore, it cannot serve as authority for the cited habitability-related proposition, and it appears to be the wrong case for that topic.
DiPalermo v. Commercial Union Ins. Co.,.relevant_excerpt: Because the entire opinion concerns criminal procedure and grand jury practice, there is no passage discussing landlord obligations, quiet enjoyment, or habitability standards. The case focuses instead on issues such as: "The issue that attracts our particular attention concerns deficiencies in the presentation of evidence to the grand jury which indicted the defendant, deficiencies that the defendant argues undercut the integrity of the grand jury proceedings and require the dismissal of the indictment."
